document.text: Winston Thornhill, Negro, was charged Saturday with breaking and entering into Percy Thomp sons Phillips 66 station, R t. 460, Appomattox. Sheriff Walter Conner, State Trooper W. W. Wilberger, and Deputy Charlie Rush recognized Thornhill and made the arrest Saturday morning at a county restaurant. Thornhill was wear ing eyeglasses allegedly taken from Thompsons station. Conn er said Thornhill has previously served time on similar charges of breaking and entering. Following a preliminary hear ing, Thornhills case was sent the Grand Jury for an April hear ing.

document.text: Walter Conner will be seeking his first full term as sheriff. He was appointed by Circuit Court Judge Joel W. Flood to fill the unexpired term of David T. Rob ertson after Robertson was kill ed in an auto accident in De cember 1960. Conner had been a deputy un der Robertson since 1950 A veteran of World War II, Conner served in the First Ar mored Division with 32 months overseas duty out of his four years, eight months in service. He attended Appomattox schools and is married to the former Miss Lucille Sheperla, of Lynch burg. The Conners have two chil dren, Neil and Donna Gail, both students at Appomattox H ig h School.

document.text: Three county office candidates made it official Saturday at the conclusion of the county Demon- cratic Committee meeting, J . T.  Irby and J . P . Harvey each filed with the chairman, Watkins Ab- bitt, as candidates for the South- side County Supervisors seat. Walter Conner, incumbent Ap pomattox County sheriff, files his intentions to run, also. Conner will be seeking his first full term as sheriff. He was appointed by Circuit Court Judge Joel W. Flood to fill the unexpired term of Dave T. Robertson, after Ro bertson was killed in an auto ac cident in Dec. 1960.

document.text: Sheriff David T. Robertson an nounced this week that he has ap pointed two part time deputies to assist in extra police duties in the county. They are Walter Phelps, at Oakville, who will act as jail guard in the absence of the jailer, and Thomas G. Catlett at Pamplin, who will serve papers, both criminal and civil, and other general law enforce ment work in the jPamplin area. .Mrs. Walter Phelps was also ap pointed Justice of the Peace, for Stonewall District, and will act as Justice of the Peace in the absence of Mrs. Walter Conner from the jail and Mrs. Vaida L. Catlett, wife of the new Pamplin deputy, will be Jus tice of the Peace for the Pamplin area, Clover Hill District. Sheriff Robertson states that Mr. and Mrs. Catlett were appointed es pecially to help the people of the Pamplin area and on request of the Town Council of Pamplin. The sheriff states that there will be no allowance for any salary for these appointees from the county treasurer, but the Justices will be paid on. a fee basis at no cost to the county, and the new deputies will receive pay according to what they do and the cases they work on, such to be approved by the sheriff and the county board of supervisors at the end of each month and the state will pay two-thirds of this amount. The fees collected by the new deputies and paid into the county treasury will offset the balance of the one- third to be paid by the county.

document.text: Sergeant Leslie L. Stanley, who retired from the State Police force Friday has announced his candidacy for Appomattox Coun ty Sheriff, opposing incumbent Walter Conner in the July 9 Democratic primary. Under Stjte Bailee regulations personnel with a! least ZS Sfears creditable service are retired at age 60. Under this regulation Stanley could have worked until Jan. 1, 1964 but chose to retire early In order to be able to run for sheriff this year. He was born Dec. 11, 1903 at Hebron Church in Appomattox County and attended Appomat tox High School. He previously worked for the Norfolk  West ern Railway and the Virginia Supply Co. of Bluenfield, W. Va. before joining the State Police June 18, 1930. document.text: Mrs. Lucy Weigand Sheper- la, age 73, of 3236 Nelson St., Lynchburg, died Friday after noon at Lynchburg General Hospital after a short illness. Her husband was the late William H. Sheperla. Born in Lynchburg, she was a daughter of the late John W. Weigand and Nellie Waldron Weigand. She was a retired employee of Craddock-Terry Sioe Corp., where she was a member of the Quarter Century Club. She was a member of Fairview United Methodist Church. She is survived by two daughters, Mrs Walter Conner of Appomattox and Mrs. Robert Falwell of Rustburg one brother, Frank H. Weigand. of Lynchburg two sisters, Mrs. Ezra Sisk and Mrs. Bettie Johnson, both of Lynchburg, four grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Funeral services were con ducted at 11 a.m. Monday at Whitten Park Avenue Chapel. Burial was in Spring Hill pnetery.

document.text: In the corporation court in Roa noke last Monday a jury returned a verdict of guilty in the case of W. L Woolridge, indicted for malicious cutting jf .his wife, fixing his punishment at three years in the penitentiary. About a yer ago, while in a drunken condition, Wool ridge attended a revival and pro fessed religion, and he then went home and made a vicious assault upon his wife, catting her throat, Mis. Woolridge recovered. Wool ridge made hia escape and was cap tured in Covington about a month ago.  Bill will be remembered in Appomattox where he lived for many years. I Monday afternoon at one oclock, at the home of Mrs. Alice Bondu rant on College Hill, Miss Bertha Mae Bonddrant was married to Mr. Lather Thomas Wright, the ring ceremony being performed by the brides pastor, Bev. W. A. Cooper. The room in which the ceremony I took place was decorated with! daises and potted ferns. The bride, who is the adopted daughter of Mrs. Alice Bond arant and the late Jas. D. Bondnrant, wore a tailored traveling suit of bine, and carrisd brides roses. Her only attendant, I Miss Ethel Hughes, of Gladys, wore I a lingerie dress and carried white sweet peap. The groom i3 the son of Mr. and Mrs?Roland Wright, of I Buckingham connty, and is em ployed by the N.  W. Railway as postal clerk., His best man was Mr. I Walter Conner. After the cere mony the couple left for a Northern trip, after which they will visit the grooms parents in Buckingham county. Among the oat-of-town I guests were Mrs. Fletcher Gibbs, of Bedford City, who played the wed ding march Mrs. Lucy Gibbs and Messrs. Harry and Paxton Gibbs, Bedford City Miss Ethel Hnghes, of Gladys, Va.and Miss Edna Wright, of Buckingham county. Lynchburg News.

document.text: Funeral serviced were hell from the Spring Creek Baptist Chur.ch, on Tuesday afternoon at 400 oclock, for Mrs. Lula Turnes Puckett 03, who died at her home in Keysville Sunday afternoon. The Rev. Edgar Stephen, her pastor, conducted the services, assisted by the Rev. E. C. Welch. Interment was in the church cemetery. Mrs. Puckett was born and rear ed in Appomattox County, a daugh ter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hay Turnes. She was an active member of the Ash Camp Baptist Church, Keysville. Surviving are her husband, Lin- wood D. Puckett, Keysville one daughter, Mrs. Edd Payne, of Dar lington Heights two. sons, Harry Puckett, of Burlington, N. C., and Richard Puckett, of Maynard, Mass. one sister, Mrs. Walter S. Bryant, of Cullen two brothers, O, Russell Turnes, of Stonewall, and W. H. Turnes, of Hopewell, and by seven grandchildren. document.text: F. L. Murphy, Chairman of the Board of Supervisors for the past 13 years announced Friday that he will not seek re - election. The other two supervisors, O. W. Martin, Jr. and Richard Webb have stated that they will seek office in the primary this year. I am not going to run due to age and health, Mr. Murphy said. Please thank the people for their support. Chairman Murphy has served continuously as chairman of the three - man board since his first election to office. He serves the Southslde District O. W. Martin, Jr., the Stonewall District and Richard M. Webb, the Clover Hill District. Cole Announces John C. Cole, Dairyman, and resident of the Souttiside District, announced Tuesday that he will file petitions in April and plans to run for the Supervisors posi tion. Filing Date Filing date for office seekers to county posts is April 10. Each candidate for a place on the Democratic primary ballot on July 9, must pay a filing fee to the county Democratic Commit tee and must submit a petition or petitions bearing at least 50 names of qualified voters. Oher Offices Open Every county office Is up be fore the voters except the Clerk of Court who is elected for an eight year term. The present of fice holders, in addition to the supervisors, are Sheriff Walter Conner, Commissioner of Reve nue John Curtis Caldwell, Com monwealth Atorney George Ab- bitt, and County Treasurer Gar land plunkett have indicated that they will run again.  Possible Opposition jjphere are,, strong indications xogt. Ir. h i Stanley -He p Stete Police, may file in April to . run against Sheriff Conner. Sgt. Stanley soon due for retire ment from the State Police force, admitted his interest in the upcoming elections, but stat ed that his present duties as law enforcement officer prevent him from making any announcement at this time. Julian Wingfield, county chair man of the Republican party, stated Saturday that he has no announcement to make immedi ately. He indicated that a county meeting of Republicans would take place in the near future.

document.text: Claude Lewis, 43, Rt. 3, Ap pomattox, received emergency j treatment from a local physician and then was admitted to Lynch- burd General Hospital Friday night following a cutting spree that allegedly took place near Wreck Island Creek bridge in this county. Sheriff Walter Conner said Saturday that he plans to charge all three men involved in the knifing with malicious wounding. Involved in the fracas were Claude Lewis, a woodcutter, Christian Carter, 31, also of Rt. 3, who works for Lewis, and Adolphus Cox, of Campbell Coun ty. Sheriff Conner reported that when he investigated the case late Friday night, he found Adol phus Cox, also at Lynchburg General, with a broken arm and bead injuries. Conner said that Carter had struck Cox with a jack hammer causing the inju ries. Carter emerged from the fracas with a scratch on his right arm and with his trousers almost slashed to shreds. Burst Into Supervisors Meeting Christian Carter burst into the Court House about 820 p.m. Fri day yelling for a doctor and say ing that there was a man cut up real bad outside. Dr. A. A. Fra trick, part of a group gath ered to hear Centennial plans, went outside to investigate gave Lewis emergency treatment for extensive knife wounds and sum moned the Appomattox Rescue Squad to carry him to the hos pital.

document.text: fense.at 2 13 made a brief statement of Mayberrys position. Floyd Trent was called as the first witness. George Abbitt ques tioned him as to the events of the afternoon and evening of Feb. 25, day on which it was alleged that the defendant shot his brother-i-n-law Jack Tucker, and then shot Dr. D. A. Christian, III as an aftermath. Trent told a straight-forward ac count of having been with the de fendant for many hours before the shooting. He said they went to the Evergreen station to . get their pay checks as railway employees, and then drove to Appomattox. He re counted the business they attended to in Appomattox that afternoon, and then related that they went to a restaurant and stayed until they drove to Evergreen to the home shared by Mayberry and his sister and his mother and his brother-in- law. He stated that to him, May berry seemed under the influence at the time. He was excused as a witness at 244. Thn M. A. Stan ley, Appomattox town officer, was called and took the stand. He told of being called to Evergreen, and how he called in County Deputy, W. S. Conner, since he, Stanley, hgd no authority in Evergreen. Stanley said that the call to Evergreen came be tween 10 andll P. M., Feb. 25, but that he left handling of the caseto county officers who had jurisdiction. He was excused at 306. Walter S. Conner, deputy sheriff, took the stand at 325. He told of answering a call to Evergreen on a report of some shooting at the Mayberry home, and that Mrs. Tucker asked that her brother be locked up, saying, hes drunk. He told of going to the Ranson Store, of meeting Floyd Trent, of return ing to the Mayberry home and see ing a body on the- back porch. He explained his returning to Appomat tox for help, and o f getting the sheriff to the - scene. He was quizzed at length as to seeing the defendant later on that night and of conversa tion with him the next day en route to Richmond where thè defendant was taken for treatment of wounds. The jury was removed while a legal point was argued .by counsel and on return of the jury, the witness said that statements made by the defen dant were voluntary. Conner was excused at 400, and Dr, C. G. OBrien was called at 401. He tes tified that he was called to Ever green and had to wait behind a car until the defendant was arrested be fore examining the body of Dr. Christian about 130 A. M. He ex plained the position of the body, and his decision as to cause and time of death. Dr. OBrien testified as to probing of the wound, said he be lieved death had been instant, at about 11 P. M. He also told of his j examination and treatment of the wounds of the defendant, and said, I found him perfectly sober. He stated that no autopsy was perform ed on the foody of Dr. Christian. He j was excused at 441, and sheriff D. I T. Robertson was called.  Sheriff Robertson related how he  had been awakened at about 11 P. I M. Feb. 25, by his deputy and ar- 1 rived at Evergreen at about 1116. I
